div.head: Discourse 4.
div.ab:
The divine and politicall lawes doe both forbid those people to marry, who are by
nature joyned in too near a degree of consanguinity, such namely as directlyascend and des
cend in a genealogicallgenealogical line, and that for very good considerations; but when the-
Philosophers speake of the mother to be joynd with the Sonne, or father with the
daughter, or of the brother with the Sister, they neither say or doe anything contrary
to the sayd laws: because subjects distinguish attributes and causes effects; for the
persons of Philosophers are asfree from those differences as well asthe Sonns and daugh
ters of Adam, who marryed one with another without the imputation of any-
crime: but the principall reason seems to be, that man=kind might be more-
firmly united and linked in affinity and freindship, and not bedivided into-
inimicallinimical and hæreditaryhereditary factions of familyes: the same reason remaining-
firme and entire in the first Sonns and daughters of Adam, did not as all de
barre them from the rightsritesof matrimony: for man=kind did then exist inrites
them alone, and noe others were living besides them, and their parents, and-
therefore as ally'dallied in blood, soe necessarily were they joyned in affinity: but
a multitude of men increasing, and being distributed into innumerable fa
milyes, this was found a true and just cause why brothers Should not marry
Sisters: The Philosophers have another reason, why Sisters may marry
brothers, namely the similitude of substance, that it may be joyned to-
the like: but in this kind there are onely two like one another as to species,
different as to sex, whereof one is saluted by the name of brother, the-
other of sister: they therefore may be the same both liberty and condi
tion, yea and inevitable necessity, as the first consanguine men, be lawfully
coḿitted to one matrimony: the brother is hott and dry, and therefore ve
ry cholerickecholeric: the Sister is cold and moist, having much phlegmatickephlegmatic-
matter in her: which natures soe differing in temper doe coḿonly best-
agree in love and fruitfullnesse, and the propagation of Children: for as
fire, which may be propagates, is not easily strucke out of the most hard
body Steel and Steel, nor out of the brittle flint and flint, but out of hard
and brittle, that is, steel and fling, soe a lively offspring is not produ
ced from a hott man and fiery woman, as neither from both cold (for the
coldnesse of the man is barrenessebarrenness) but from him hott, her more cold,-
for, in the latitude of humane temperament, the hottest woman is con
cludes colder than the coldest man of his sex, if sound, as Lev. Lemnius
in lib. de occ. nat. mirat. proves: the Sister therefore and brother are
rightly joyned together by the Philosophers: If a man defines offspring
from a henne, bitch, Shee goat, Ewe, or other brutes, hee joynes a dogge
cocke, dogge, hee goat, ramme, every animall to its Species, to which it is
most like, and soe is not frustrated of his desire; nor indeed doth hee-
respect the consanguinity of brutes, but onely the generosity of every
one, and the congruity of nature: Soe may it be sayd of the body of a tree,
and the slippe to be therein grafted, yea of the metallicke-

nature, which notwithstanding as it hath of all things the greatest-
similitude and homogeneity of substance, doth soe require, where it
desires a thing to be joyned with it: But brother and Sister being joynd
together, doe not become fruitfull, nor persist long in love, except a Philo
thesium, or cup of love be administred to them like an amorous potion:-
for their minds are hereby soe quieted and united, that (laying aside mo
desty) they doe as it were drunke (like Lot) goe together, and procreate-
an offspring (not spurious but) legitimate: For who knowes not that man
kind is very much obliged to medicine, because many thousands of men-
are now in the world, which would not have been, if their fathers or fore
fathers had not by the means and benefit thereof been freed and delivered
from the defect of sterility, or their mothers præservesfrom abortion, by removing-
and taking away the cause, or the nearest, and remote impediment? This
cup of love is therfore given to this new marryd couple for the same reasons,
which any man may hereby plainly understand are three, that is to say,-
constancy of love, remotion of sterility, and prævention of abortion. .
